Sentence: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: At our meeting that concluded earlier today, my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 1 to 1¼ percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This accommodative policy should support some further strengthening in the job market and a return to 2 percent inflation, consistent with our statutory objectives.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We also decided that in October we will begin the balance sheet normalization program that we outlined in June.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This program will reduce our securities holdings in a gradual and predictable manner.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’ll have more to say about these decisions shortly, but first I’ll review recent economic developments and the outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As we expected, and smoothing through some variation from quarter to quarter, economic activity has been rising moderately so far this year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Household spending has been supported by ongoing strength in the job market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Business investment has picked up, and exports have shown greater strength this year, in part reflecting improved economic conditions abroad.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Overall, we expect that the economy will continue to expand at a moderate pace over the next few years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: In the third quarter, however, economic growth will be held down by the severe disruptions caused by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As activity resumes and rebuilding gets under way, growth likely will bounce back.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Based on past experience, these effects are unlikely to materially alter the course of the national economy beyond the next couple of quarters.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Of course, for the families and communities that have been devastated by the storms, recovery will take time, and on behalf of the Federal Reserve, let me express our sympathy for in August—a solid rate of growth that remained well above estimates of the pace necessary to absorb new entrants to the labor force.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We know from some timely indicators, such as initial claims for unemployment insurance, that the hurricanes severely disrupted the labor market in the affected areas, and payroll employment may be substantially affected in September.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: However, such effects should unwind relatively quickly.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Meanwhile, the unemployment rate has stayed low in recent months and, at 4.4 percent in August, was modestly below the median of FOMC participants’ estimates of its longer-run normal level.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Participation in the labor force has changed little, both recently and over the past four years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Given the underlying downward trend in participation stemming largely from the aging of the U.S. population, a relatively steady participation rate is a further sign of improving conditions in the labor market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We expect that the job market will strengthen somewhat further.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Turning to inflation, the 12-month change in the price index for personal consumption expenditures was 1.4 percent in July, down noticeably from earlier in the year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Core inflation—which excludes the volatile food and energy categories—has also moved lower.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: For quite some time, inflation has been running below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: However, we believe this year’s shortfall in inflation primarily reflects developments that are largely unrelated to broader economic conditions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: For example, one-off reductions earlier this year in certain categories of prices, such as wireless telephone services, are currently holding down inflation, but these effects should be transitory.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Such developments are not uncommon and, as long as inflation expectations remain reasonably well anchored, are not of great concern inflation, but only temporarily.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: More broadly, with employment near assessments of its maximum sustainable level and the labor market continuing to strengthen, the Committee continues to expect inflation to move up and stabilize around 2 percent over the next couple of years, in line with our longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Nonetheless, our understanding of the forces driving inflation is imperfect, and in light of the unexpected lower inflation readings this year, the Committee is monitoring inflation developments closely.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As always, the Committee is prepared to adjust monetary policy as needed to achieve its inflation and employment objectives over the medium term.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Let me turn to the economic projections that Committee participants submitted for this meeting, which now extend through 2020.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As always, participants conditioned their projections on their own individual views of appropriate monetary policy, which, in turn, depend on each participant’s assessments of the many factors that shape the outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The median projection for growth of inflation-adjusted gross domestic product, or real GDP, is 2.4 percent this year and about 2 percent in 2018 and 2019.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: By 2020, the median growth projection moderates to 1.8 percent, in line with its estimated longer-run rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The median projection for the unemployment rate stands at 4.3 percent in the fourth quarter of this year and runs a little above 4 percent over the next three years, modestly below the median estimate of its longer-run normal rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Finally, the median inflation projection is 1.6 percent this year, 1.9 percent next year, and 2 percent in 2019 and 2020.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Compared with the projections made in June, real GDP growth is a touch stronger this year, and inflation—particularly core inflation—is slightly softer this year maintain its target for the federal funds rate, we continue to expect that the ongoing strength of the economy will warrant gradual increases in that rate to sustain a healthy labor market and stabilize inflation around our 2 percent longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That expectation is based on our view that the federal funds rate remains somewhat below its neutral level—that is, the level that is neither expansionary nor contractionary and keeps the economy operating on an even keel.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Because the neutral rate currently appears to be quite low by historical standards, the federal funds rate would not have to rise much further to get to a neutral policy stance.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But because we also expect the neutral level of the federal funds rate to rise somewhat over time, additional gradual rate hikes are likely to be appropriate over the next few years to sustain the economic expansion.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Even so, the Committee continues to anticipate that the longer-run neutral level of the federal funds rate is likely to remain below levels that prevailed in previous decades.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This view is consistent with participants’ projections of appropriate monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The median projection for the federal funds rate is 1.4 percent at the end of this year, 2.1 percent at the end of next year, 2.7 percent at the end of 2019, and 2.9 percent in 2020.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Compared with the projections made in June, the median path for the federal funds rate is essentially unchanged, although the median estimate of the longer-run normal value edged down to 2.8 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As always, the economic outlook is highly uncertain, and participants will adjust their assessments of the appropriate path for the federal funds rate in response to changes to their economic outlooks and views of the risks to their outlooks.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Policy is not on a preset course.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As I noted, the Committee announced today that it will begin its balance sheet normalization program in October.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: This program, which was described in the June addendum to result, our balance sheet will decline gradually and predictably.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: For October through December, the decline in our securities holdings will be capped at $6 billion per month for Treasuries and $4 billion per month for agencies.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: These caps will gradually rise over the course of the following year to maximums of $30 billion per month for Treasuries and $20 billion per month for agency securities and will remain in place through the process of normalizing the size of our balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: By limiting the volume of securities that private investors will have to absorb as we reduce our holdings, the caps should guard against outsized moves in interest rates and other potential market strains.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Finally, as we have noted previously, changing the target range for the federal funds rate is our primary means of adjusting the stance of monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Our balance sheet is not intended to be an active tool for monetary policy in normal times.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We therefore do not plan on making adjustments to our balance sheet normalization program.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, of course, as we stated in June, the Committee would be prepared to resume reinvestments if a material deterioration in the economic outlook were to warrant a sizable reduction in the federal funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’d be happy to take your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Chris Condon, Bloomberg News.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, there’s been extraordinary progress during your term as Chair in lowering several measures of unemployment and underemployment, and all while inflation has remained subdued.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON.

Sentence: But some people are even asking, why stop there?
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON.

Sentence: Bill Spriggs, the chief economist at the AFL-CIO, who I think you know well, criticized the Fed last week for seeking to maintain unemployment above 4 percent, which he notes necessarily means keeping the unemployment rate among black the Fed’s preferred measure of inflation has not exceeded 3 percent in more than 25 years.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON.

Sentence: So I’m wondering how you would respond to his frustration over the Fed’s desire to continue raising rates when core inflation really shows no sign of heading above the Fed’s symmetric goal for inflation.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON.

Sentence: So let me first say that employment is a very important part of our mandate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We’re charged by Congress with trying to pursue maximum employment, and we have taken that very seriously.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’m very pleased and heartened by the improvement we have seen in the labor market, and at 4.4 percent, the unemployment rate has really fallen to quite a low level.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As that’s happened, the unemployment rates for less advantaged groups in the labor market, particularly African Americans and Hispanics, has fallen more dramatically than that for the nation as a whole, reversing the outsized increases that those groups experienced when the financial crisis and Great Recession hit.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And these are really very positive developments.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So we certainly seek a strong labor market, but we have a dual mandate, which is inflation and unemployment, and we also have to be mindful of our obligation to achieve a 2 percent inflation objective over the medium term.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, I recognize and it’s important that inflation has been running under our 2 percent objective for a number of years, and that is a concern, particularly if it were to translate into lower inflation expectations.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: For a number of years there were very understandable reasons for that shortfall, and they included quite a lot of slack in the labor market—which, my judgment would be, has largely disappeared—very large reductions in energy prices, and a large mystery, and I will not say that the Committee clearly understands what the causes are of that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, we do, in our regular projection, show fan charts indicating the typical size of forecast errors.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: All of the variables—GDP, the unemployment rate, and inflation—are forecast by ourselves and private forecasters with errors, and so there is variation in these economic variables from year to year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I would say our judgment, as I said in the statement, is that the shortfall is not largely related to cyclical considerations.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You can see from the projections that the Committee participants submitted that we anticipate that core and headline inflation will move up close to our 2 percent objective next year—namely, that the shortfall this year is due to transitory factors that are likely to disappear over the course of the coming year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I want to emphasize that we do have a commitment to raising inflation to 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And as we watch incoming data, the assessments that you see participants write down about the path of the federal funds rate, they are not set in stone.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: They are not definite plans.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We will look at incoming data on inflation and on other economic variables, including the labor market, in deciding what we should actually do going forward.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And if it proves contrary to our expectations that the shortfall is persistent, it will be necessary to adjust monetary policy to address that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I want to point out that while there are risks that inflation could continue below 2 percent, which we need to take account of in monetary policy, monetary policy also operates with a lag.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And experience suggests that tightness in the labor market, gradually and with a lag, tends to push up wage and price inflation, and that’s also a risk, that we want to be careful not to allow the economy to overheat in a way that would force us later on, somewhere down the road, to have to tighten monetary policy rapidly, which could cause a recession and threaten the very Fed’s staff spoke recently about elevated asset prices in the markets in the most recent—in the meeting before this one held today.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: How are buoyant market conditions affecting the debate at the moment about how quickly to rein in stimulus?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And have they, in your own mind, helped to counter some of the concerns you’ve had about the inflation shortfalls that we’ve been seeing?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thanks.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So at every meeting we try to assess the economic outlook and take account of information that’s been accumulated about the real economy and also developments in financial markets and put all of that together in assessing the course of the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So developments affecting asset prices and longer-term interest rates, the exchange rate—all of those aspects of financial conditions factor into our thinking.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But it’s not easy to get a clear read on the implications of asset prices for the overall outlook.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Sometimes movements—upward movements in asset prices can, for example, reflect a change in market participants’—reduction in market participants’ estimates of the longer-run level of interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So there has been—there have been downward revisions both to the Committee’s and to market participants’ estimates of the longer-run normal level of interest rates, which in turn reflects in some sense a view that, going out many years, aggregate demand globally is likely to be weakened by continuing low productivity growth and aging populations.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, of course, we don’t know if that view is correct, but that’s a factor that could be reflected—could be one reason why asset prices have moved as they have.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, you know, why are asset prices moving?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That’s important in determining the impact on the overall outlook, but, certainly, we are taking account of movements in asset prices in evaluating the appropriate stance of opening remarks that reducing the balance sheet should not be “an active tool for monetary policy in normal times,” you don’t plan to make adjustments to the balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’m wondering if we could explore if there’s any sensitivity to the plan you just announced if there’s a spike in interest rates, a plunge in the stock market, weakness in growth.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: In the June statement, you indicated that the only reason why you would change the—it suggested the only reason you’d change the balance sheet is if it required, first, a change in the funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Is that true?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: If there’s some unexpected development in markets, or, for example, given that we don’t know what the plans are on the fiscal side for the deficit in terms of tax cuts—there could be a sudden spike in the deficit—will the balance sheet reduction plan be immune to all of that?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, given that question, and the idea that this has never been done before, why so much certainty about the plan you’ve just announced and apparent unwillingness to adjust it?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So we have two policy tools that are available to us to use:  the balance sheet and adjustments in short-term interest rates—our federal funds rate target.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, historically, the Committee has operated to adjust monetary conditions to meet our economic goals when there are shocks to the economy by adjusting the federal funds rate—our short-term interest rate target.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And that’s something—a technique of monetary control that we have used for a very long time that we are familiar with, we believe we understand pretty well what the effects are on the economy, market participants understand how that tool has been used and would likely be adjusted in response to shocks to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And our preference is, when we have two different tools that we could use to actively adjust the stance of policy, to prefer and to the threat to the economy is sufficiently great that we might have to cut the federal funds rate—after all, we’ve moved it up to 1 to 1¼ percent and expect it to go up further—but a very significant negative shock to the economy could conceivably force us back to the so-called zero lower bound.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have said if there were that type of material deterioration in the outlook where we could face a situation where the federal funds rate isn’t a sufficient tool for us to adjust monetary policy, we might stop—we might stop roll-offs from our balance sheet and resume reinvestment.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But as long as we believe that we can use the federal funds rate as a tool, that is what we intend to do.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, if there are small changes in the outlook that require a recalibration of monetary policy, we will change our anticipated path and setting of the federal funds rate, but not, for example, change the caps on reinvestment or stop—continue reinvestment for a few months and then change it.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We think that provides greater clarity to market participants about how policy will be conducted and will be, will be less confusing and more effective in terms of conducting policy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Binya Appelbaum, the New York Times.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You have now committed to a policy of reducing your balance sheet very gradually.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You have described plans to raise interest rates even more gradually than previously.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: You are locked in for a long period of time to a forecast that monetary policy will essentially keep interest rates at a low level and keep a balance sheet at a high level.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: If something goes wrong, does the Fed have room to respond under these conditions in the next several years, and could you describe for us what your “locked in,” and I would say that we are not locked in.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: We believe that economic conditions will evolve in a way that will warrant gradual, further increases in our federal funds rate target, but if conditions evolve differently than that, whichever direction that might be—it might be that growth is more rapid, the labor market tightens more quickly than we assume, and inflation appears to be picking up more rapidly than we had expected—we have not promised, no matter what, that the path of interest rate increases will be gradual.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: We believe that that will be appropriate, but we always watching the economy and will adjust policy as appropriate.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: Now, as I said, the hurdle to changing our plans with respect to the balance sheet, in some sense, is high.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: If conditions were to weaken, we would really only consider resuming reinvestment if it were what we refer to as a material deterioration, and I tried to explain why that is.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: But, you know, we will adjust monetary policy.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: What you see in the dot plot is each participant’s best guess, based on the information they have today, about what will be appropriate in light of their expectations about how the economy would evolve.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: And we think it’s helpful to show the public some sense that it helps in understanding our evaluation of the economy.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: But we’re assessing incoming data, and these plans are subject to change.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: What’s not subject to change is our commitment to doing everything in our power to achieve the goals that Congress has assigned to us, which are price stability or 2 percent inflation and maximum employment.
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: Do you, in fact, have room in the next two or three years to respond to an economic downturn?
Speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

Sentence: So, certainly, if growth is stronger or if inflation picks up more over the next couple of years, which will give us greater room, and we think the recovery is on a strong track.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So the reason for our actions today in beginning to run down the balance sheet is, we think the economy is performing well and we have confidence in the outlook for the real economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, of course, there are shocks, and if the negative shock to the economy were sufficient, we recognize that we might be unable to pursue objectives purely by cutting the federal funds rate, and that is why we say explicitly that we would be prepared, in that event, to resume reinvestment, and other tools that we used in the financial crisis—forward guidance—would also be available to us.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, Fed Governor Lael Brainard recently gave a speech in which she said trend inflation appeared to have moved lower by around ½ percentage point.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: I wanted to ask, do you agree?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: And what would the Fed need to do, if anything, to boost trend inflation if it has fallen?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: And, related to that, you’ve said you expect the inflation softness this year to prove “transitory.”  Compared to three months ago, how firm is your current expectation that the slowdown will remain transitory, and what implications would that have for monetary policy if it is not?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentence: So the term “trend inflation”—usually there are a variety of statistical techniques that can be used to extract a trend from a series.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Exactly what that means is, in some sense, a statistical thing, and there are methodologies that would show some modest decline in recent years in the trend.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: After all, we’ve had a number of years in which inflation has been low.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: As I said in answer to an earlier question, I think if you go back to, say, 2013 and consider the—import price inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So what’s important in determining inflation going forward is inflation expectations.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: By some—by many—by some survey measures of professional forecasters, those have been rock solid.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We do also look at household expectations, which have come down some.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Market-based measures of inflation compensation, as we mentioned in the statement—they have declined, and they’ve been stable in recent months, but they’ve declined to levels that are low by historical standards.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: That might suggest that inflation expectations have come down, but one can’t get a clear read—there are risk premia built into inflation compensation that make it impossible to extract directly what inflation expectations are.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, you know, there is a miss this year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I can’t say I can easily point to a sufficient set of factors that explain this year why inflation has been this low.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’ve mentioned a few idiosyncratic things, but, frankly, the low inflation is more broad based than just idiosyncratic things.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: The fact that inflation is unusually low this year does not mean that that’s going to continue.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Remember that in January and February, core inflation was running over a 12-month basis at around 1.9 percent, and we look to be very close to 2 now.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We’ve had several months of data that have meaningfully pulled that down, and what we need to do is figure out whether or not the factors that have lowered inflation are likely to prove persistent or they’re likely to prove transitory, and that’s what we’re going to try to be determining on the basis of incoming data.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And you asked me about the policy implications.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Of course, if we determined our view changed, and instead of thinking that the factors holding inflation down were transitory, we came to the view that they would be persistent, it would require an alteration in monetary policy to pricing in still a shallower path of rate hikes than the Fed does in the SEP, and I wonder, what do you think that markets might be missing here, and, sort of, what’s your conviction about, you know, that your view is the correct one on the gradual—the pace that “gradual” means, which seems to be a little bit faster than what markets are pricing?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So I’m not really going to try to explain what market participants are thinking.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I think all of us—both market and FOMC participants’ paths have come down.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Not in the last couple of quarters, but over the last several years, there’s been a growing recognition that the so-called neutral interest rate, consistent with the economy operating at maximum employment, that that rate seems to have come down, and most of the economic papers and research bearing on this topic suggest that it’s quite low.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Market—SEP—the FOMC participants—you can see by their estimates of the longer-run normal rate of interest, it is—this time it came down from—the median came down from 3 percent to 2.75 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So that shows that even in the long run, FOMC participants, in light of incoming data, are adjusting their views.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I would say they still believe that, in real terms, that neutral rate will be rising somewhat over the next few years.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: With a 2 percent inflation rate, that long-run estimate in real terms amounts to 75 basis points, which is higher than the zero or slightly positive rates now.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So that’s one factor that explains the path in the SEP.  Market participants may have lower estimates or believe that a low neutral rate may be more persistent.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I mean, let me emphasize that, as I said before, there’s nothing set in stone about the policy paths that you see in the summary of projections.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There’s a great deal of uncertainty around them.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Not only is there disagreement, there’s also uncertainty, and FOMC participants in the SEP and market-implied paths.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: One is that FOMC participants are writing down what they think is the most likely, or modal, outcome for rates.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, of course, there are downside risks.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And the mean rate, if they were asked to write that down, would take account of weighing all possible outcomes and likely would be lower than what participants are writing down as their most likely outcome.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: In addition, in markets, many economists have suggested that there are term premia that can affect moving from the so-called market-implied path to the view for what the future federal funds rate path is, and if those term premia are negative, as many economists think they likely are, there’s a little bit less difference between what you see in the FOMC plot and the market-implied plot.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Thanks.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: Jim Puzzanghera with the L.A. Times.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, your term expires as Chair in February.
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: Have you had a chance to meet with or discuss your situation with President Trump yet?
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: And if so, what were your impressions of him and what he’s looking for from the Federal Reserve?
Speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA.

Sentence: So I have said that I intend to serve out my term as Chair, and that I’m really not going to comment on my intentions beyond that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I will say that I have not had a further meeting with President Trump.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I met with him early in my term, and I’ve not had a further meeting with him.1 ADAM SHAPIRO.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Adam Shapiro, Fox Business.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Chair Yellen, a month ago you delivered a speech in Wyoming in which you said, “The balance of research suggests that the core reforms we have put in place have substantially boosted resilience without unduly limiting credit availability or economic growth.”  I have a two-part question based on that quote.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: First,                                                  then, regarding economic growth, the accommodative process that the Fed has followed for the last 10 years has helped bring us to full employment, but economists point out that there have been people who haven’t benefited.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: For instance, 52 percent of Americans own stock, 48 percent don’t—they’ve not participated in the gains in the stock market.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Housing prices—the median house price is now at a record high, and 39 million Americans, according to a Harvard study, spend more than 30 percent for housing.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So what would you say to those people about Fed policies and the impact they’ve had on their lives?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Okay.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So you asked me, what was the main—first, what was the main message of my speech, and I would say it’s that we put in place, since the financial crisis, a set of core reforms that have strengthened the financial system, and, in my personal view, it’s important they remain in place.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And those core reforms are more capital, higher-quality capital, more liquidity—especially in systemically important banking institutions—stress testing, and resolution plans.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And those four prongs of improvements in banking supervision have really strengthened the financial system and made it more resilient, and I believe they should stay in place.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But I also tried to emphasize—and I believe that they have contributed to growth and the availability of credit.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’ve also tried to emphasize that all regulators should be attentive to undue regulatory burden and look for ways to try to scale that back.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And this is especially true after years in which we have implemented a large number of complex regulations, and we have been committed to doing that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I would point out particularly community banks that are laboring under significant regulatory burden.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have been looking for ways to scale back burdens, running the important.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: More generally, we want to tailor—we want to, and we would like to see Congress as well—we can do things to appropriately tailor regulations to the risk posed by different kinds of banking organizations.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There are some things that Congress could also do to help that process, and we have made some concrete suggestions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And then some of the regulations that we have put in place with other regulators since the crisis, like the Volcker rule, are really quite complex, and we’re working—we believe we should—and we’re working with other regulators to try to see if we can find ways, while carrying out what Dodd-Frank intended, that banking organizations not be involved in proprietary trading.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Nevertheless, the implementation can be less complex.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So that was my main message.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Your second question asked about what impact the Fed has had on income distribution because of the fact that stocks and homes tend to be disproportionately owned.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, I would say, look, we were faced with a huge recession that took an enormous toll in terms of depriving large numbers of people—and disproportionately lower-income people who are less advantaged in the labor market—found themselves without work.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We had a 10 percent unemployment rate, and our congressional mandate is maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So we set monetary policy not with a view toward affecting the distribution of income, but toward pursuing those congressionally mandated goals.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And I am pleased to see the unemployment rate and every other measure that I know of pertaining to the labor market show dramatic improvement over these years, and that is hugely real terms rise significantly, with gains throughout the income distribution.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Marty Crutsinger, Associated Press.
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: Madam Chair, the next month, with the departure of Vice Chair Fischer, the Fed’s going to lose its quorum—the Fed Board—you’ll go to three members.
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: Do you have—is that going to present operational challenges for you?
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: Do have contingency plans?
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: Has the Senate assured you that Mr. Quarles will be—his confirmation will be approved?
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: And in your discussions with the Administration, have they given you any assurances that the pace of nominations is going to pick up soon?
Speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER.

Sentence: So first let me say that I will greatly miss Vice Chair Fischer.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: He’s made enormous contributions to the FOMC and to the broader work of the Federal Reserve, and I have really enjoyed working with him and appreciated his wise counsel and friendship.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It is conceivable that we will be down to three Governors.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I have full confidence that even if that happens, we will be able to carry out our complement of responsibilities.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: There’s—every action that we are allowed to take under the Federal Reserve Act can be taken, even if we are a Board of three, although we will have to abide, as we always do, by the restrictions that are part of the Government in the Sunshine Act.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I would welcome a full complement of colleagues.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We have a lot of work to do, and it would be nice to distribute it over more people.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But, perhaps more important than that, I think it’s very important to have a broad range of views around the table as we deliberate on policy actions.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’ve had very good interactions with Randy Quarles and hope he will be confirmed.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I look forward to working with him, and, you know, I hope that the Administration will make considering a major tax reform package.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Do you or any of the Committee members have concerns if that package does not end up being deficit neutral and ends up adding to the debt?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Would that be problematic for the economy?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Look, that’s something that’s a matter for Congress and the White House to decide.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You know, I’ve put forward a few principles about fiscal policy that I would reiterate, that one of the problems that the American economy suffers from, along with many other economies around the globe, is slow productivity growth, and I think it would be very desirable if a fiscal package had the potential in it to create incentives that would raise productivity growth.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We do face, in terms of longer-term deficits as the population ages, an unsustainable debt path that will require, I believe, some adjustments to fiscal policy, and I hope Congress will keep that in mind.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But beyond a few core principles, it’s really—I don’t want to weigh in on details.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer from Marketplace.
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentence: When you testified before Congress last July, you said that you might be prepared to take enforcement actions against Wells Fargo if it proved to be appropriate.
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentence: Do you think it’s appropriate, and what actions could you take?
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentence: So let me say that I consider the behavior of Wells Fargo towards its customers to have been egregious and unacceptable.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We take our supervision responsibilities at the company very seriously, and we are attempting to understand what the root causes of those problems are and to address them.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I’m not able to discuss confidential supervisory information controls are in place in that organization.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Can you give me any kind of a timeline?
Speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER.

Sentence: We are working very hard on it.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Hi, thank you.
Speaker: DAVID HARRISON.

Sentence: David Harrison with Dow Jones.
Speaker: DAVID HARRISON.

Sentence: I’d like to follow up on the balance sheet question, if I may.
Speaker: DAVID HARRISON.

Sentence: What specifically would it take for you to reverse the decision to wind down the balance sheet, and under what conditions would you consider adding to the balance sheet again?
Speaker: DAVID HARRISON.

Sentence: And separately, as a follow-up to that, looking more broadly, how do you think history will judge the effectiveness of your asset purchases and the conditions under which that policy should be used?
Speaker: DAVID HARRISON.

Sentence: Thank you.
Speaker: DAVID HARRISON.

Sentence: So, starting with the last part of the question, I mean, my own judgment, based on my experience and the economic research that has tried to estimate the effectiveness of our balance sheet actions starting in 2008 and has also looked at the similar balance sheet actions in other parts of the world, including the euro area, is that these actions were successful in making financial conditions more accommodative and, I believe, in stimulating a faster recovery than we otherwise would have had.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: A recent Fed working paper estimated that the full set of balance sheet actions that we took during the crisis may have lowered long-term interest rates by about 100 basis points.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Obviously, there are different—there are different estimates around—of what difference it made, but I would say that it’s effective.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It will be up to future policymakers to decide, in the event of a severe downturn, whether they think it’s appropriate to again resort to balance sheet—to adding assets to a balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I would say that if economists are correct that we’re living in a world where the level of neutral bear out to be correct, but it is a view that many people adhere to when there is evidence of it—then future policymakers will be faced with the question of, in the event of a severe downturn where they’re not able to provide as much stimulus as they would ideally like by cutting overnight interest rates, what other actions are available to them?
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And during the crisis, we bought longer-term assets and used forward guidance, and for my own part, I would want to keep those things in the toolkit as being available.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: It will be up to future policymakers to decide how to rank those, or whether or not there might be other options that are available to them, but I don’t think this issue will go away, although perhaps it’s only—well, this could well be a decision that future policymakers will have to face in the event of a significant asset—economic shock.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I mean, you asked me what would it take for us to resume reinvestment, and I can’t really say much more than we said in the guidance that we provided, which is that if there is a material deterioration in the economic outlook and we thought we might be faced with a situation where we would need to substantially cut the federal funds rate and could be limited by the so-called zero lower bound, it is that type of determination that our Committee is saying would—might lead us to resume reinvestment.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So that’s—our Committee has been unanimous in affirming this statement of intentions, so, you know, I think that’s where our Committee stands.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So that is a somewhat high bar to resume reinvestments, and that’s why, in answering previous questions, I would say, well, you know, if there’s some small, negative shock, our first tool—our most important and reliable tool—will be the federal funds rate.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: But if there is a significant shock that’s a material the Financial Stability Oversight Council for a few years now, and I was wondering if you had any thoughts on whether the designation process for Systemically Important Financial Institutions should be changed or improved in any way.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And a somewhat separate, but related, question:  The situation with Equifax—I was wondering if there’s anything related to that that might raise systemic issues that FSOC would need to discuss.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So you asked first about the designation process.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So during the time that I’ve been on the FSOC, only one firm was—several firms were designated before I participated.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: MetLife was designated during the time that I was there, and I have seen how the designation process works.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: I do think designation is important.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We saw during the financial crisis that some systemically important nonbanking organizations like Lehman and AIG—that their distress produced broad systemic consequences that were adverse for the U.S. economy.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And having the ability to designate firms when the FSOC makes the determination that their distress or failure could have systemic repercussions, I believe that’s an important—that’s an important policy tool for FSOC to have available.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Now, it’s not meant to be a one-way street, in the sense that a firm that’s designated—the procedures require annual reviews.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Firms may change their business models or just how they conduct their business, and we should welcome de-designation of firms if their business model is changed in a way that leads us to believe that their failure or distress would no longer be systemically important and those are decisions that we make every year.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: So, you know, I’m satisfied with that process so far.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: GE Capital dramatically changed its you know, glad to consider them as, you know, part of the FSOC process, but I think it’s been important and basically working.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: You asked about Equifax and, you know, of course that is a very serious data breach.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: We would really urge consumers now to be very careful in monitoring their credit reports and financial situation.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And, through our supervision, we’re working with the banks that we supervise to make sure that they take appropriate actions with respect to their business processes in light of the fact that there could be breaches or fraudulent transactions or information that they received that they might use—for example, in credit determinations—could be contaminated by bad data.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: More generally, it points to the importance of strong cybersecurity controls and attention to cybersecurity risks, which we do see as one of the most significant risks to the financial sector.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And we are very focused in our banking supervision in making sure that banks have appropriate controls in place.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: And the Equifax breach, I think, highlights the importance of that.
Speaker: CHAIR YELLEN.

Sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Television and Radio.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: We’ve talked a lot today about what you’re going to do and what you may do, but not necessarily about why.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: With four rate increases behind you, financial conditions are looser than before you began.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And I’m wondering if that bothers you, if you’re concerned about overstimulating the economy, or if you feel inflation could break out much more quickly than we have seen, or if you feel there’s a financial stability question because stocks, bonds, and real estate are all so expensive now.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: How would you explain what the Fed is doing, why the Fed is doing it, to the American about rates and today about our balance sheet are ones we’ve taken because we feel the U.S. economy is performing well.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: We are working down our balance sheet because we feel that’s stimulus that in some sense is no longer needed.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: So the basic message here is, U.S. economic performance has been good.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: The labor market has strengthened substantially.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Every measure of the labor market, whether it’s the narrow unemployment rate, the broader unemployment rate, the number of people working in part-time jobs who want full-time work, the level of job openings, the quit rate, the difficulty that firms are facing in hiring workers, the level of confidence we see in surveys about the labor market—all of that is pointing to vast and continuing improvement in the labor market.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And we see sufficient strength in the economy, in terms of spending—that growth, with its ups and downs, but nevertheless is strong enough—looks to be strong enough in the medium term to support ongoing improvement in the labor market.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And all of that is good, and I think that the American people should feel the steps we’re taking to normalize monetary policy are ones that we feel are well justified, given the very substantial progress we’ve seen in the economy.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: Now, inflation is running below where we want it to be, and we’ve talked about that a lot during this—the last hour.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: This past year, where it’s not clear what the reasons are—I think it’s not been mysterious in the past, but, one way or another, we have had four or five years in which inflation is running below our 2 percent objective, and we are also committed to achieving that.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: So the monetary policy path that we follow and the paths that my colleagues are writing down in market on a sustainable basis.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And in making these judgments about the path of policy, we have to balance various risks.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: One risk is that if we tighten policy too quickly, we may find out that, although we don’t think this now, that the inflation shortfall is something that’s going to be persistent.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And if we tighten too quickly, we could undermine inflation performance—leave it at too low a level—inflation expectations could fall, and that could become ingrained, and that would be dangerous.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And so that’s a reason to be cautious about raising interest rates when inflation is as low as it is.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: But, on the other hand, we have a strong labor market and a low unemployment rate.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: And although the pace of job gains is not quite as strong this year as, for example, as it was in 2016, we’re still averaging 175,000 jobs a month this year, which is quite a bit above the pace of maybe 100 to 120,000 that would be consistent with a stable unemployment rate if labor force participation begins to move down in the manner we expect.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: So if we don’t do anything to remove policy accommodation, and the labor market tightens and just continues to tighten, as you mentioned, arguably—we could, you know—arguably, financial conditions overall haven’t tightened that much.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: We think the economy could overheat, inflation could rise more quickly and above our objective.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: That’s something that would occur with a lag, and that would force us later on to tighten policy more rapidly than would be ideal, and we could risk a recession if we did that.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentence: So there are risks on both sides to our objectives, and most of my colleagues and I have concluded that a gradual path of rate increases—while constantly watching incoming data, being open to revising our views on the outlook, and revising our expectations about policy—is the
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.
